Though I tend to be philosophical about it--if we destroy the Earth at a rate like the Precambrian extinction event, that still leaves 5% of species alive. And those will be the cows, cats, dogs, rats, pigeons, chickens, raccoons, pigs, ducks, geese, oxen, and other species that humber in their billions. A few thousands of those animals are bound to survive and then radiate outward in an evolutionary explosion once we kill ourselves off. To quote Jurassic Park, "Life finds a way."

Yeah, we're disastrous and dumb, like a huge asteroid. An individual human is pretty smart, capable and alert, able to course-correct quickly for the most part when things go wrong. 7.5 billion of us together, however, are a huge and brutish natural disaster, blindly destroying everything in our path. Even when we gather in a crowd of hundreds or thousands we are a huge danger--terrifying, bestial stampedes of humans have been known to kill hundreds or thousands of other humans by crushing them underfoot. It happened a lot in history. We are locusts, we are a plague, when we gather together in huge numbers.

After the Cambrian explosion things got really messy; plant life got sick of trilobites exploding and coating them with gunk. So a bunch of them decided to move to the land and left the whole mess to the fish to clean up. Fish being fond of trilobite goo were rather excited and filled the seas. Arthropods got the short end of the stick and after being mocked by plants decided to get even and move onto the land. Fish of course as we all are notoriously envious animals. Seeing that Arthropods and Plants weren't sharing they decided to grow some legs and move there as well. From that point on everything became a general mess with nobody happy even unto this day.

The thing that scares me most about climate change is reaching the runaway greenhouse bit. A mere major mass extinction is recoverable; the Earth has a good billion years of life-support left before the sun makes surface life difficult if not impossible. Plenty of time to re-evolve complexity. But if we trigger a runaway event, and the Earth becomes Venus' twin, that won't happen. :(

Fantastic video, but there were a few inaccuracies that are worth mentioning.

Stegosaurus, featured in the Cretaceous-Paleogene Mass Extinction image, is a strictly late Jurassic taxon, not a late Cretaceous one, and thus it wasn't extant at the time of the Cretaceous-Paleogene Mass Extinction.
In addition, Dimetrodon, which was featured in the Permian-Triassic Mass Extinction image, has a "taxonomic lifespan" spanning from about 295 million years ago to about 272 million years ago, but the Permian-Triassic Mass Extinction happens roughly 20 million years later, around 252 million years ago.

Hope this helps!

Leftist propagada. No one denies climate change or that humans have affected the biosphere, but mass extinction due to human activity and CO2 levels is the end of life as we know it is a major exaggeration. CO2 is plant food and supports the greening of the planet. Global warming could make growing plants in marginal areas more difficult if one assumes that humans become dumb and unable to innovate solutions, but newly warming areas will expand the area where crops can grow. Technology and science will solve food problems and environmental degradation to the dismay of catastrophists.

On a more positive note, I have noticed a bit of a shift in people's perspectives, at least here on YouTube: I remember a time (a couple of years ago) when a video such as this, concerning the dangers of unrestrained human development, would have gotten at least 30% dislikes. Not necessarily from climate change deniers, just people who were fed up with hearing about the same old environmental issues.
If this video's 5% dislike ratio is in any way significant, then I'm glad to see that at least some people have begun to realize that this is in fact an important and pressing matter.
